ğŸŒ¿ Today, we celebrate the International Day of Wetlands! ğŸ’§This day, celebrated every 2nd of February, commemorates the adoption of the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands in 1971. This year's theme is "Wetlands and Human Well-being," emphasizing the interconnection between human well-being and the health of wetlands worldwide. The conservation and restoration of wetlands are crucial in addressing climate and biodiversity crises, aligning with sustainable development goals for the benefit of all. Let's recall some of the benefits of wetlands: * Many endangered species depend on wetlands for survival. * They absorb excess rainwater, preventing floods and damage to constructions. * They absorb carbon, and if destroyed, could become a source of significant greenhouse gas emissions. * And much more! On this day, let's reflect on the impact of the construction of Vlora International Airport, which will challenge the delicate ecosystem of the Narta Lagoon. This area was a Protected Area (IUCN Protected Landscape / Category V) for its high ecological value until 2022. We hope that the relevant authorities take necessary measures to limit the damage, emphasizing that achieving a zero-impact airport is impossible. In the long term, the consequences of airport construction may outweigh the benefits, including economic aspects.

Six months ago, I did a talk at the annual CLIA in Europe conference. The theme was sustainability, and exploring ways the industry can move forward in an environmentally engaged manner. The debate was lively, the presentations well attended, and the subsequent conversations genuinely absorbing. But one conversation stood out. I'd mentioned a project in my speech, one that would find, celebrate, and bring profile to marine community conservation initiatives. From saying those words, to Ben Bouldin stepping in to offer support for the project was about ten minutes. For that support to be realised from Royal Caribbean Group took about four weeks - a remarkably short turnaround. For the project itself to take place took four months. And now, here we sit, looking back at what I'm euphemistically terming phase one, but what was essentially a summer that encountered and filmed numerous community supported conservation projects along our coastline. The film below is a short summary of that project, what it might bring in the future as a template for further conservation work in creating more citizen science initiatives, and how we might enable local people to get stuck in to their own area of coastline by using these examples. Next film out this Friday by the way! #marine #community #support #conservation #environment
